message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Epidemics on multilayer simplicial complexes
Paper Abstract: Simplicial complexes describe the simple fact that in social networks a link can connect more than two individuals. As we show here, this has far-reaching consequences for epidemic spreading, in particular in the context of a multilayer network model, where one layer is a virtual social network and the other one is a physical contact network. The social network layer is responsible for the transmission of information via pairwise or higher order 2-simplex interactions among individuals, while the physical layer is responsible for the epidemic spreading. We use the microscopic Markov chain approach to derive the probability transition equations and to determine epidemic outbreak thresholds. We further support these results with Monte Carlo simulations, which are in good agreement, thus confirming the analytical tractability of the proposed model. We find that information transmission rates are frequently low when actual disease transmission rates in the physical network are low or medium, and we show that this can be mitigated effectively by introducing 2-simplex interactions in the social network. The relative ease of introducing higher-order interactions in virtual social networks means that this could be exploited to inhibit epidemic outbreaks.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Markov chain"

Links: [{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Continuous-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Discrete-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain approximation method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_approximation_method"},{"title":"Markov chain tree theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_tree_theorem"},{"title":"Quantum Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain mixing time - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_mixing_time"},{"title":"Markov chain central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Markov Chains and Mixing Times - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_Chains_and_Mixing_Times"}]

## Markov Chain - Overview

A Markov chain (or Markov process) is a stochastic process describing a sequence of possible events in which the probability of each event depends only on the state attained in the previous event.(no content)Informally, this may be thought of as, "What happens next depends only on the state of affairs now."

### Key Characteristics

Markov processes are named in honor of the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov. There are two main types:

- A discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC) is a countably infinite sequence in which the chain moves state at discrete time steps.
- A continuous-time process is called a continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC).

### Applications

Markov chains have many applications as statistical models of real-world processes and provide the basis for general stochastic simulation methods known as Markov chain Monte Carlo, which are used for simulating sampling from complex probability distributions.

Links: [{"title":"Multidimensional network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multidimensional_network"},{"title":"Multilayer perceptron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_perceptron"},{"title":"Feedforward neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedforward_neural_network"},{"title":"Network entropy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_of_network_ensembles"},{"title":"Recurrent neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network"},{"title":"Ginestra Bianconi - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ginestra_Bianconi"},{"title":"Multilayer switch - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilayer_switch"},{"title":"Routing protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Routing_protocol"},{"title":"Deep backward stochastic differential equation method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_backward_stochastic_differential_equation_method"},{"title":"Time delay neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_delay_neural_network"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of multilayer networks:

## Multilayer Networks

In network theory, multilayer networks are networks with multiple kinds of relations.(no content)Real world networks often have added complexity in the form of multiple types of relations between system elements.

### Applications and Significance

Increasingly sophisticated attempts to model real-world systems as multilayer networks have yielded valuable insight in the fields of social network analysis, economics, urban and international transport, ecology, psychology, medicine, biology, commerce, climatology, physics, computational neuroscience, operations management, and finance.

### Research Complexity

Given the higher complexity of multilayer networks with respect to unidimensional networks, an active field of research is devoted to simplify the structure of such systems by employing some kind of dimensionality reduction.

### Diffusion Processes

An important aspect of multilayer network research involves understanding how processes spread through these systems. Diffusion in multiplex networks exhibits two regimes: 1) the weight of inter-layer links is not high enough and the multiplex system behaves like uncoupled networks; 2) the weight of inter-layer links is high enough that layers are coupled, raising unexpected physical phenomena.

The study of multilayer networks has become increasingly important for understanding complex systems where entities interact through multiple types of relationships simultaneously.

Links: [{"title":"Direct simulation Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_simulation_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Monte Carlo method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_method"},{"title":"Monte Carlo methods in finance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_methods_in_finance"},{"title":"// - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_simulation_modelling_of_industrial_systems"},{"title":"Monte Carlo methods for electron transport - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monte_Carlo_methods_for_electron_transport"},{"title":"Multilevel Monte Carlo method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilevel_Monte_Carlo_method"},{"title":"Subset simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subset_simulation"},{"title":"Carmonette - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carmonette"},{"title":"Poker calculator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poker_calculator"},{"title":"Category:Monte Carlo methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Monte_Carlo_methods"}]

## Monte Carlo Simulation

Here's an overview of Monte Carlo simulation based on the search results:

### Definition
Monte Carlo methods are a broad class of computational algorithms that rely on repeated random sampling to obtain numerical results.(no content)The underlying concept is to use randomness to solve problems that might be deterministic in principle.

### History and Naming
The name comes from the Monte Carlo Casino in Monaco, where mathematician Stanisław Ulam was inspired by his uncle's gambling habits.(no content)In the late 1940s, Stanisław Ulam invented the modern version of the Markov Chain Monte Carlo method while working on nuclear weapons projects at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

### Applications
Monte Carlo methods are mainly used in three distinct problem classes: optimization, numerical integration, and generating draws from a probability distribution.(no content)They can also be used to model phenomena with significant uncertainty in inputs, such as calculating the risk of a nuclear power plant failure, and can provide approximate solutions to problems that are otherwise intractable or too complex to analyze mathematically.

### Specific Use Cases
Monte Carlo simulations are applied across various fields, including:
- **Finance**: In valuing options on equity, the simulation generates several thousand possible price paths for the underlying share, with the associated exercise value of the option for each path, which are then averaged and discounted to today.
- **Physics**: In physics-related problems, Monte Carlo methods are useful for simulating systems with many coupled degrees of freedom, such as fluids, disordered materials, and strongly coupled solids.

## Monte Carlo Simulation

Here's an overview of Monte Carlo simulation based on the search results:

### Definition
Monte Carlo methods are a broad class of computational algorithms that rely on repeated random sampling to obtain numerical results.(no content)The underlying concept is to use randomness to solve problems that might be deterministic in principle.

### History and Naming
The name comes from the Monte Carlo Casino in Monaco, where mathematician Stanisław Ulam was inspired by his uncle's gambling habits.(no content)In the late 1940s, Stanisław Ulam invented the modern version of the Markov Chain Monte Carlo method while working on nuclear weapons projects at the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

### Applications
Monte Carlo methods are mainly used in three distinct problem classes: optimization, numerical integration, and generating draws from a probability distribution.(no content)They can also be used to model phenomena with significant uncertainty in inputs, such as calculating the risk of a nuclear power plant failure, and can provide approximate solutions to problems that are otherwise intractable or too complex to analyze mathematically.

### Specific Use Cases
Monte Carlo simulations are applied across various fields, including:
- **Finance**: In valuing options on equity, the simulation generates several thousand possible price paths for the underlying share, with the associated exercise value of the option for each path, which are then averaged and discounted to today.
- **Physics**: In physics-related problems, Monte Carlo methods are useful for simulating systems with many coupled degrees of freedom, such as fluids, disordered materials, and strongly coupled solids.

Here are the search results for "Simplicial complexes":

## Definition

In mathematics, a simplicial complex is a structured set of simplices (for example, points, line segments, triangles, and their n-dimensional counterparts) such that all the faces and intersections of the elements are also included in the set.

## Abstract Simplicial Complexes

An abstract simplicial complex (ASC), often called an abstract complex or just a complex, is a family of sets that is closed under taking subsets. It is a purely combinatorial description of the geometric notion of a simplicial complex.

## Applications

Simplicial complexes have important applications in mathematics and computer science:

- **Topological Data Analysis**: Simplicial homology has become important for application to real-life situations, such as image analysis, medical imaging, and data analysis in general.

- **Data Structures**: In topological data analysis, a simplex tree is a type of trie used to represent efficiently any general simplicial complex, which explicitly represents all the simplices.

## Related Concepts

In algebraic topology, simplicial homology is the sequence of homology groups of a simplicial complex, which formalizes the idea of the number of holes of a given dimension in the complex.

Links: [{"title":"Compartmental models (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compartmental_models_(epidemiology)"},{"title":"Mathematical modelling of infectious diseases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_modelling_of_infectious_diseases"},{"title":"Epidemic models on lattices - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_models_on_lattices"},{"title":"Epidemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic"},{"title":"Epidemiological transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemiological_transition"},{"title":"Kermack–McKendrick theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kermack–McKendrick_theory"},{"title":"Endemic (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic_disease"},{"title":"Superspreading event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superspreading_event"},{"title":"List of epidemics and pandemics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_epidemics_and_pandemics"},{"title":"Complex contagion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_contagion"}]

I've completed the web search for "Epidemic model disease spreading." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Mathematical models can project how infectious diseases progress to show the likely outcome of an epidemic and help inform public health interventions.

## Basic Concepts

An epidemic is the rapid spread of disease to a large number of hosts in a given population within a short period of time.(no content)Epidemics can be modeled as diseases spreading over networks of contact between people, which can be represented mathematically with a graph called the contact network.

## Compartmental Models

Compartmental models are a mathematical framework used to simulate how populations move between different states or "compartments." While widely applied in various fields, they have become particularly fundamental to the mathematical modelling of infectious diseases. In these models, the population is divided into compartments labeled with shorthand notation – most commonly S, I, and R, representing Susceptible, Infectious, and Recovered individuals.(no content)The SIR model is one of the simplest compartmental models, and many models are derivatives of this basic form.

## Key Parameters

This quantity determines whether the infection will increase sub-exponentially, die out, or remain constant: if R0 > 1, then each person on average infects more than one other person so the disease will spread; if R0 < 1, then each person infects fewer than one person on average so the disease will die out; and if R0 = 1, then each person will infect on average exactly one other person, so the disease will become endemic.

## Applications

Epidemiologists and public health officials use these models for several critical purposes: analyzing disease transmission dynamics, projecting the total number of infections and recoveries over time, estimating key epidemiological parameters such as the basic reproduction number (R0) or effective reproduction number (Rt), evaluating potential impacts of different public health interventions before implementation, and informing evidence-based policy decisions during disease outbreaks.

Links: [{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"The Social Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Network"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Distributed social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_social_network"},{"title":"Gab (social network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gab.com"},{"title":"Social Networks (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Networks_(journal)"},{"title":"The Social Reckoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Reckoning"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about social networks:

## Definition and Structure

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Social Networking Services

In the digital context, a social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)Social networking sites are generally defined as "websites that facilitate the building of a network of contacts in order to exchange various types of content online", and they allow users to share ideas, digital photos and videos, posts, and to inform others about online or real-world activities and events with people within their social network.

## Historical Development

Jacob Moreno is credited with developing the first sociograms in the 1930s to study interpersonal relationships, and these approaches were mathematically formalized in the 1950s with theories and methods of social networks becoming pervasive in the social and behavioral sciences by the 1980s.(no content)Early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), with many of these early communities focused on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms.

## Global Adoption

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

Jacob Moreno is credited with developing the first sociograms in the 1930s to study interpersonal relationships, and these approaches were mathematically formalized in the 1950s with theories and methods of social networks becoming pervasive in the social and behavioral sciences by the 1980s.(no content)Early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), with many of these early communities focused on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms.

## Global Adoption

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)
Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! Analysis complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes a novel framework combining simplicial complexes with multilayer networks to model epidemics.

**Identified Triples (6 total):**

1. **Simplicial complex** (concept) - `proposes` - The paper applies this mathematical structure to represent higher-order interactions in networks.

2. **Multidimensional network** (concept) - `uses` - Framework for combining social and physical network layers.

3. **Social network** (concept) - `uses` - Serves as one layer in the multilayer model for information transmission.

4. **Compartmental models (epidemiology)** (method) - `uses` - Applied for studying disease transmission and outbreak thresholds.

5. **Markov chain** (method) - `uses` - Used to derive probability transition equations for epidemic dynamics.

6. **Monte Carlo method** (tool) - `uses` - Employed for validating analytical results through simulations.

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED - All 6 triples are properly formatted with correct Wikipedia URLs and meet all validation requirements.
